qas.question: What was each private lodge required to provide to the Clerk of Peace every week?
Why did English Freemasonry almost come to a halt in 1699?

context: In <a5_0>1799<a5_0/>, English Freemasonry almost came to a halt due to <a0_0><a6_0><b10_0><b14_0>Parliamentary proclamation<b14_0/><b10_0/><a6_0/><a0_0/>. In the wake of the French Revolution, <a7_0>the Unlawful Societies Act <a2_0><b12_0>1799<b12_0/><a7_0/><a2_0/> banned any <a1_0><b11_0>meetings of groups that required their members to take an oath or obligation<b11_0/><a1_0/>. The Grand Masters of both the Moderns and the Antients Grand Lodges called on <a4_0><a8_0>Prime Minister William Pitt<a8_0/><a4_0/> (who was not a Freemason) and explained to him that Freemasonry was a supporter of the law and lawfully constituted authority and was much involved in charitable work. As a result, Freemasonry was specifically exempted from the terms of the Act, provided that each private lodge's Secretary placed with the local "Clerk of the Peace" <a3_0><b13_0>a list of the members of his lodge<b13_0/><a3_0/> once a year. This continued until <a9_0>1967<a9_0/> when the obligation of the provision was rescinded by Parliament.
